column1: 76ers also have a much better team around Embiid, with another all-star and great defensive player in Simmons, and a borderline all-star in Tobias. Oh, and his backup is Dwight Howard, while Jokic is backed up by Isaiah Hartenstein...

Nuggets fan here:   We lost Jeremi grant, Mason Plumlee, and Torrey Craig- which was almost our entire bench unit. Jeremi would come to be a starter and then we‚Äôd pull Millsap off the bench, but yeah, our team didn‚Äôt get better. Isaiah Hartenstein was signed to replace plumlee but has not been playing well and he‚Äôs the only other center on our roster besides Jokic.  Combine that with nagging injuries to Jamal Murray, Gary Harris, and now even PJ Dozier. Our team is being forced to play 3rd string players significant minutes and play our remaining starters too many minutes.   We‚Äôve even attempted small ball (maybe even considered ‚Äúmicro ball‚Äù) lineups, with 4 small guards and Jamykel Green at center, who are always outmatched and cannot make up for their size.   The off-season was not kind to us and even though I believe we could still make a splash in the playoffs with reduced rotation, we‚Äôre going to have trouble getting a good spot with a healthy bunch at this rate.

As a Rockets fan, when healthy he was pretty effective against the likes of Rudy, Jokic (beating him down the court), AD (Pels version), and KAT. It was just the Rockets intense focus on beating the Warriors and Green‚Äôs hyper-intelligent approach to dropping back on the lob threat and sitting on Clint‚Äôs legs that motivated Harden to develop an effective floater right before the Unguardable Tour season (where btw he had to play that way bc significant time missed by CP3, Clint, and Eric Gordon). Clint‚Äôs lob was the release valve the Rockets were missing when trading him for RoCo. The Rockets thought they could pick up Nerlen‚Äôs from the Thunder at some point but ironically CP3 and the ‚Äúprofessionals‚Äù as I call them (Gallo, Dennis) had them winning so they retained Nerlens. Also now known is that they reportedly offered Isaiah Hartenstein and 2SRP for Wood last season to be that guy. Never got a Clint-lite or comparable in time for Harden and Russ to use.

One word keeps playing in my mind as I watch quietly in the background this NBA season. Disrespect. Disrespect for Hartenstein's game, his skill, his impact. People treating him like he's not a NBA caliber player. People thinking rookie's are better than him. It's all so very disrespectful. Let's make one thing very Clear. Hartenstein will make the Hall of Fame. He is that GREAT.  **THERE IS A DIFFERENCE BETWEEN NOT PLAYING AND PLAYING BADLY.**  For young players it doesn't matter how many minutes you get, it only matters what you do with the playing time you do get. Hartenstein in his career has only played 6 games over 20 minutes. In those games he was 5-1 with a plus minus of +88. The last time Hartenstein played 20 minutes in a game Hartenstein had 17/15/1/2stls/5blks shooting 89% from the field in only 26 minutes of play. Hart was a +39. Now, I want to put that specific stat line in perspective. For one, it's the only time in NBA history a player put up at least 17/15/5blks/2stls on 89% shooting, but more than that, it's the +39 that is unreal. Jokic's career high plus minus is +38. Hartenstein in 26 minutes put up a higher plus minus than Jokic's career high. But it's not just Jokic. Lebron's career high plus minus was also +39. Think about the greatness of Lebron, his longevity, his dominance. Think about how many absolutely terrible teams Lebron has played over his career. Only once was Lebron as dominate from a plus minus perspective as Hartenstein that night.  If this was only a one time thing I wouldn't really care. Many players have fluke historic games. Booker dropped 73, Cory Brewer and Terrence Ross dropped 50. I'm sure if you look though history you will find plus minus performances better than Hart and Lebron's career high. But here's the important detail. It's NOT a one time thing. Hartenstein is constantly a positive helping his team win games. This season **Isaiah Hartenstein leads the Denver Nuggets in net rating.** Not Jokic, not Murray, HARTENSTEIN. When Hartenstein plays the Nuggets are WINNING. The Nuggets are 7-1 when Hartenstein plays more than 11 minutes. Hart is a +64 in those games.  So the obvious question is HOW? How is it Hartenstein is leading the Nuggets in net rating? From a eye test prospective he's been struggling. One word my friend. **DEFENSE.** Requiring at least 25 games played **Isaiah Hartenstein leads all centers in defensive rating.** Hart is averaging 3.3 blocks and 2.1 steals per 100 possessions. Hart is the only player in the NBA that averages 3+ blocks and 2+ steals per100 possessions while being positive in the plus minus. To put those stats into prospective, Kevin Garrett only Averaged 3 blocks and 2 steals per 100 possessions once in his NBA career, the year he won MVP. Isaiah Hartenstein leads the Nuggets in net rating because he's currently playing defense at a similar level to MVP KG. [quick highlight of what I'm talking about](https://streamable.com/n5spcy)  **In Hartenstein Prime he could win DPOY.** That said I'm not sure this level of defense will keep up. This level of defense is probably a simple a flash of what Hartenstein could become defensively. Kind of like how Jokic showed flashes of averaging triple doubles when he was 22-23 years old. We might see some regression defensively, but any regression defensively will be more than compensated for what Hartenstein will give the Nuggets offensively.  Hartenstein has been in a horribly timed shooting slump, Hart is shooting just 53% at the rim (he shot 79% at the rim last season), the game is still fast for him. However Hart will improve dramatically with playing time. I know this because it's not the first time Hartenstein has been in a shooting slump in limited minutes. When Hartenstein played with the Rockets, in the games Hart played less than 15 minutes he averaged per36 11/6/1stl/1blk shooting 51% from the field. Hartenstein struggles when he doesn't get constant playing time. Because **Hartenstein never gets constant playing time**, all people see are the struggles. They don't see what happens when he gets playing time. In the Games Hartenstein played more than 15 minutes he averaged per36 17/16/2blks/1stl shooting 75% from the field. When Hartenstein gets playing time he does the same thing he did in the G-League. Dominates.  The main thing that prompted this post was the last two Nuggets games I saw back to back. The Nuggets played the Grizzles and then Played the Mavericks. One game Hartenstein played, the other game Hartenstein didn't. Jokic, Barton and MPJ played great in both games, Murray Struggled in both games. one game the Nuggets won, the other they were blown out. This back to back was the perfect microcosm of Hartenstein's value as a player.  Hart was the only bench player positive in the plus minus during the Grizzles game, he had 2 blocks and 1 steal in 11 minutes of play. Hartenstein had a defensive rating of 65 in that game. The Nuggets couldn't hit anything, Murray shot 7% in the game, Campazzo was missing open threes, Dozier was 1 of 6. Jokic was coming out after the Grizzles hit an unbelievable deep three to cut the lead to 4. When Jokic came back at the 6 minute mark, the lead was still 4. Nuggets end up winning by one point. Hartenstein didn't take a shot during that stretch, but what he did do is contest every shot, he got deflections steals, blocks. Hartenstein didn't foul. If the Grizzlies went on a run during that stretch jokic was out the Nuggets would have lost. As such **Hartenstein play won the Grizzlies game**  Comparatively, The Nuggets played a back to back against the Mavericks. Malone choose to go with the 20 year old rookie Nnaji instead of Hartenstein and that decision lost the game. Now understand Nnaji is a good player, he can put the ball in the basket and I think he will be in the NBA for a long time. But he is not ready for NBA rotation minutes without Hartenstein or Jokic backing him up. In the Minutes Nnaji plays without Jokic or Hart the Nuggets are -30 net rating. Again Nnaji is good, but he's a rook and he plays like a rook. In this Mavericks game, once then Nuggets put in Nnai the Nuggets gave up layups. So many layups the Nuggets lost the momentum and by the time Jokic came back in the game he couldn't stop the bleeding. The Mavs are too good to not play Isaiah Hartenstein.  So where do we go from here? I want to give advice to 3 people. Malone, Nuggets Fans, and Hartenstein himself.  **For Malone:** I want you to know that I love you. I love your coaching style and I respect you. Truly. Both Jokic and Hartenstein were second round picks, but you gave Jokic a real opportunity to show his talent. You said "I wouldn't trade Jokic for anybody in the world" when Jokic was a rookie. Without that opportunity you gave Jokic I don't know where the Nuggets would be. Hartenstein didn't get that opportunity, he was instead sent to the G-League. Hartenstein dominated the G-League, he was the youngest G-League finals MVP in history. His reward for playing great? getting cut. So my advice to you Malone is nothing crazy, just play Hartenstein the same minutes you would have given Plumlee. Hartenstien is not Plumlee, he's much better. But still, that's all he needs. Plumlee never played less than ten minutes, never play Hartenstein less than ten minutes. Let the Young player grow.  **For Nuggets Fans:** Have patience. I understand that Hartenstein doesn't look the best right now. I understand he fouls a lot, I understand he is shooting really bad at the rim. But the Numbers don't lie. When Hartenstein plays basketball the Nuggets are a better team than when Jokic plays basketball. That is not an opinion, that is a fact. MPJ had a 0/8 shooting game, he's still a clear STAR. Hartenstein is the same age as MPJ and should be treated with the same level of understanding. The fouls will end, the finishing will come, and Hartenstein Greatness will begin.  **For Hartenstein:** I believe in you. At times it must feel like no one does. Like no one understands how versatile and great you can be. **Don't give up.** Keep working, keep grinding. Your time will come. hopefully with the Nuggets but if not, that's fine too. Isaiah **YOU ARE GREAT. YOU ARE AMAZING. YOU WILL WIN CHAMPIONSHIPS**

Ideal?  PG: Cade Cunningham; Darius Garland; Matthew Dellavedova  SG: Steph Curry; Colin Sexton; Dylan Windler  SF: LeBron James; Isaac Okoro; Cedi Osman  PF: Larry Nance Jr; Dean Wade;   C: Jarrett Allen; Isaiah Hartenstein;  Definitely ECF, probably winning another ring

PG: Cole Anthony  SG: Payton Pritchard  SF: Terrence Ross  C: Domantas Sabonis  PF: Jerami Grant  Bench: Mike James, Isaiah Hartenstein, Nigel Williams-Goss, Terrence Jones  Btw we counting guys like Kevin Love?

I have a lot of affection for a lot of the players on the Cavs, but in my honest opinion, Sexton, Nance, and Allen are basically the only players on our roster that I would consider to be "good" right now.  Garland has a ton of potential and looked great at times last season, Okoro has a ton of potential, Dean Wade and Isaiah Hartenstein are lovable memes who sometimes do fun things on the court.  But those three are the only ones I think your average team would want as starters or sixth men as they are right now.  And of the three, the only really consistent one is Sexton.  Nance is consistently good when he's healthy, but he's not a stat sheet stuffer.  And Allen was kind of hot and cold all season.

A lot of those things in your first part played into health at the time.  And it wasn't CP3 versus Russ. That's the story the media has been talking about. But the Rockets didn't play House for a couple months just to be under the luxury tax in 2019, when he was arguably their third best healthy player. They didn't play Gary Clark to stay under the luxury tax. They spent *multiple* picks to get under the luxury tax when they had expirings they could have traded for rotation players. They yoyoed  Isaiah Hartenstein. Played people like Terrence Jones and James Nunnally for a couple games with no practice just to make the money work. Austin Rivers got cut from the Suns and the Rockets made him a starter.   2019 was all about the Rockets spending picks to stay under the cap and keeping good young players on 10 days and in the g league instead of getting them minutes to be useful in the playoffs.

If they need a Center, Aron Baynes, Bismack Biyombo, Boogie, Ed Davis, Isaiah Hartenstein, Luke Kornet, or Kevin Love are probably the only options realistically available. None of those guys are that attractive, though Baynes and Hartenstein I think would be most likely to develop at all, where everyone else I'd say has definitely passed their peak.  Boogie might make the most sense depending on Love's financial desires and the relationship he had with the Lakers as he left. Otherwise, if I'm them, I'm calling Baynes just to have a pretty serviceable, albeit probably below average, starting option.   Hartenstein is also interesting, as he's never really played many games, and he's managed 3 teams in his 3 years, but the kid's only 22 and put up good efficiency (20.3 PER and .62 TS% with a .151 WS/48 and 1.3 BPM) for Cleveland in his limited play, including 2 starts. It would essentially be like drafting a 7-foot European prospect who you know has a low ceiling, which is not bad at all if you could get him for a minimum.  Love I'd say is option #4 - he arguably had the highest peak (maybe Boogie?) and fits the "we know how to win, and hope to remember despite our age" ethos of the Lakers lineup at the moment. I think bringing in someone under 33 would be helpful, I think starting a C over 6'8" would be helpful, and I think having a more traditional C to keep AD happy would make a certain amount of sense, but Love would be an asset off the bench to any team in the NBA rn, so I don't think he's a bad pick by any means.

Available right now, who could put in minutes at C more usefully than the husk of DeAndre Jordan?  Tacko Fall, Isaiah Hartenstein, Thon Maker - but wait, they're young and have potential to get better, rather than being old and declining, the Lakers don't do that now.

I think Draymond is amazing and does a lot that doesn't show up in either the stat sheet or the advanced stat sheet. When he's motivated, he does such a great job covering for all his teammates, it's insane.  To supplement this, I looked at players with at least 100 DFGA. That comes out to approx. 5 shots defended per game in the 17-19 games so far this season.  https://www.nba.com/stats/players/defense-dash-overall/?Season=2021-22&SeasonType=Regular%20Season&PerMode=Totals&sort=PCT_PLUSMINUS&dir=1&CF=D_FGA*GE*100  Rudy's also been amazing, if I may say so myself. He's defended the most shots so far this season, with 330 DFGA and holding opponents to 38.2%, with an expected FG% of 46.2%, an 8% difference. You have to go all the way down to Deni Avdija's 203 DFGA to find a player who has a bigger absolute margin (35.0% - 43.8% = 8.8%). Draymond's at 180 shots defended with (40.6% - 45.3% = -4.8%, rounding presumably).  (Bold: Outliers, Italics: OP mentioned)  Other effective players include:  * **Rudy Gobert: 330 shots defended, DFG% - FG% = -8%** * Mo Bamba: 300 DFGA, -5.4% * Myles Turner: 280 DFGA, -4.3% * John Collins: 279 DFGA, -5.2% * *Giannis Antetokounmpo: 249 DFGA, -2.2%* * Jaren Jackson Jr.: 222 DFGA, -6.0% * *Paul George: 220 DFGA, -0.4%* * Kevin Durant: 212 DFGA, -3.9% * Devin Booker: 208 DFGA, -3.4% * Isaiah Stewart: 204 DFGA, -5.5% * **Deni Avdija**: 203 DFGA, -8.8% * *Deandre Ayton: 198 DFGA, -0.5%* * Bobby Portis: 194 DFGA, -5.9% * Luguentz Dort: 192 DFGA, -4.4% * LaMelo Ball: 190 DFGA, -6.3% * Davion Mitchell: 188 DFGA, -6.4% * Isaiah Hartenstein: 184 DFGA, -6.5% * *Draymond Green: 180 DFGA, -4.8%* * Bam Adebayo: 176 DFGA, -8.6% * **Derrick Rose**: 146 DFGA, -12.8%, with a DFG% of 30.8%! * Joel Embiid: 146 DFGA, -6.8% * Luke Kennard: 138 DFGA, -7.6% * **Patrick Beverley**: 122 DFGA, -11.9% * **Matisse Thybulle**: 114 DFGA, -11.3% * **Eric Gordon**: 115 DFGA, -10.5% * Austin Reaves: 106 DFGA, -7.6%  More players if the DFGA threshold is lowered to 75 include Mike Muscala (-14.8%!), Taj Gibson, DeAndre' Bembry, Tony Bradley, Jaxson Hayes, Landry Shamet(?), ...  Ineffective players include:  * **Kyle Lowry: 216 DFGA, +8.8%** (wtf) * **Dejounte Murray: 205 DFGA, +8.3%** (he was in the conversation of all-D) * Kemba Walker: 188 DFGA, +6.9% * Ja Morant: 179 DFGA, +7.1% * Luka Doncic: 178 DFGA, +6.1% * Darius Garland: 170 DFGA, +7.5% * Saddiq Bey: 159 DFGA, +7.4% * Cade Cunningham: 153 DFGA, +6.2% * **Bojan Bogdanovic**: 148 DFGA, +10.1% (ugh this lines up with the eye test) * Kyle Anderson: 135 DFGA, +11.2% * Donovan Mitchell: 129 DFGA, +8.7% (this one too) * Cody Zeller: 104 DFGA, +12.0% * Facundo Campazzo: 100 DFGA, +11.2%  A lot more players pop up if the DFGA threshold is lowered to 75, including Xavier Tillman, Gary Harris, Chuma Okeke, Kira Lewis Jr., Chimezie Metu, ...   Disclaimer: DFG% can be unfair, especially if you're a player who's always asked to defend the opposing team's best player. Royce O'Neale gets screwed by the difficulty of his defensive assignments, so I find it really impressive his DFG% difference is -0.6%, despite getting put on everyone from KD to DeRozan to Booker to Tatum to Ja.
